newsitem.title: UK: Most UK finance bosses favour tax rises - survey.
newsitem.headline: Most UK finance bosses favour tax rises - survey.

text.p: More than half of Britain's finance directors think the next government should raise taxes to fund election commitments, a survey out on Thursday showed.

Some 55 percent of the 200 finance directors polled by Accountancy/Reed Accountancy Personnel said the next government should raise taxes to pay for improvements in education, the health service, law and order and other commitments.
And 58 percent of them believe it will do so.
An election is due on May 1 and the opposition Labour Party is riding high in the polls although the latest suggests the gap might be closing.

"While more than half of those surveyed can see the benefit of raising additional revenue through increased taxation, many are adamant that taxes should not be raised," said David Callaghan, director of Reed Accountancy Personnel.
Only 37 percent of the directors surveyed were against tax inreases but most of those were resigned to the fact that taxes would rise regardless of who takes power.

"Whilst most agree that any political party would be foolish to fight the election on a tax-raising policy, by far the majority of financial directors believe that taxes will rise after the election has been won, no matter who come out the winners," Callaghan said.
